q2.value: Tarek Masoud | Sharan Grewal | Elizabeth Nugent

q9.value: A version of the experiment was conducted in June 2016. We are re-fielding the experiment in 2017 and pre-registering before commencing.

q15.value: Political life in Arabic-speaking, Muslim-majority countries has long been marked by the electoral dominance of political parties and movements that seek to apply some version of scripturally-derived Islamic law, or shari`a. One prominent explanation for the popularity of these movements is that their religious characteristics strike a chord among immiserated populations suering from the dislocations of urbanization, modernization, and authoritarianism. In this telling, which draws on Durkheim's (1897) theory of social change and anomie, the embrace of religious parties is one piece of a broader turn toward the comforting certainties of religion during times of upheaval. In this study, we conduct one of the fi rst experimental tests of this hypothesis. Subjects will be randomly assigned to experimental treatments that cue feelings of economic and social hardship. These treatments include vignettes adapted from Mani et al (2013) as well as behavioral games that induce income loss due to coordination failure. After receipt of treatment, we measure respondents' post-treatment attitudes toward religion in general, Islamic political parties, and support for shari`a. We hypothesize that those who have been subject to economic and social strain will exhibit higher levels of trust in Islamist parties, will be more supportive of the implementation of shari`a in general, and are more likely to subscribe to conservative, Orthodox interpretations of shari`a in particular. This approach supplements two strands of recent scholarship on support for Islamism: One that has tended to ascribe the appeal of Islamist parties to material factors such as organizational prowess or the provision of social services; and another that has viewed these parties' religious nature as merely allowing them to signal competence or trustworthiness to low-information voters.

q16.value: Subjects will be administered a post-treatment survey that measures their attitudes toward Islamism and shariah. We also collect information on education, income level, profession, employment status, age, and gender. We also collect information on past voting behavior. Our main goal is to observe whether assignment to treatments cueing economic strain render subjects more supportive of Islamist parties and share`a. We also explore heterogeneous treatment effects--particularly income, employment status, age, and gender.

q17.value: 1. Recipients of economic strain stimuli will be more supportive of Islamic parties and of shari`a (as revealed by scores on post-treatment questions) than those in the control group. 1a. Poor respondents (as measured by education level, income, employment status) who receive the economic strain stimuli will be more supportive of Islamic parties and of sharia than more affluent respondents who receive the stimuli. 1b. Women who receive the economic strain stimulus react differently than men.

q27.value: Researchers, Logistical help in recruiting subjects, hosting the experiment, and administering treatment provided by One-to-One Research and Polling, Tunis, Tunisia

attributes.title: Electoral Rules, Gender, and Legislators’ Responsiveness: Field Experiments from Europe and Latin America

q1.value: Electoral Rules, Gender, and Legislators’ Responsiveness: Field Experiments from Europe and Latin America

q2.value: Gabriele Magni | Zoila Ponce de Leon

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: An important aspect of representation concerns legislators’ responsiveness to constituents. The experimental literature on legislators’ responsiveness in American politics has focused mostly on racial bias, while one study in Europe has explored the role of intrinsic and extrinsic motivations as shaped by different electoral rules). In this paper, we bring together previous work by exploring how identity (defined in terms of gender) and electoral institutions affect the responsiveness of elected officials. We do so through a comparative field experiment that is conducted in 11 countries, 5 from Europe and 6 from Latin America.

q16.value: H1: The gender of the sender does not affect the overall response rate of MPs H2: MPs are more responsive to constituents of their own gender (i.e. female MPs to female constituents) H3: In Latin America, female MPs are more responsive than male MPs H4: MPs in Europe are more responsive than MPs in Latin America H5: The response rate is higher for MPs elected in a majoritarian electoral system or open-list PR system (i.e. with preferences) compared to closed-list PR systems H6: The response rate is higher for MPs belonging to parties on the left H7: The response rate is higher for MPs belonging to parties in government. This effect is expected to be larger for closed-list PR systems (i.e. without preferences) H8: District magnitude and constituency size have a positive impact on MP’s response rate

q17.value: We will calculate the difference of means for answers sent to the female and the male sender. A Student’s T-test will be used. We will also use regression with the covariates listed below to test whether MPs’ individual characteristics influence the response rate.

q18.value: Netherlands, Ireland, Germany, Italy, United Kingdom, Colombia, Brazil, Argentina, Guatemala, Mexico, Chile

attributes.title: Political Party Organization and Women’s Empowerment

q1.value: Political Party Organization and Women’s Empowerment

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: Women in many developing countries face significant barriers to effective political participation in local politics, and this may be a crucial roadblock in a positively reinforcing relationship between political and economic empowerment of women. What are the effects of increasing women’s political participation at the grassroots? We examine this question through a randomized field experiment conducted around the December 2016 elections in Ghana. While we cannot manipulate women’s participation directly, we can encourage their participation through a civic education campaign. The treatment is a durbar -- a large community meeting presided over by the traditional chief -- held in rural villages by Ghana’s National Commission for Civic Education (NCCE), an independent, non-partisan government agency that regularly conducts civic education programs. The goal of the civic education treatment is to address social norms against the participation of women in political parties and encourage greater women’s participation at the local level in the period leading up to the December 2016 election. We assess the effect of the durbar on (a) women’s political participation; (b) political party strategies, including mobilization and outreach to women before the election; (c) women’s economic welfare; and (d) social norms about the participation of women in politics and local leadership. (1) The experiment is an opportunity to understand how the resources available to political parties affect their electoral and linkage strategies in new democracies. Particularly important in new democracies are labor resources – the grassroots members and “brokers” capable of mobilizing or persuading voters through networks of personal relationships. It has been difficult to assess how these resources affect party behavior, however, as parties often simultaneously differ on many dimensions, and political competition affects both the resources available to a party and the mix of strategies it selects. We address this issue by randomizing treatment over rural communities to exogenously increase the participation of women in local party branches that begin with very similar initial resource endowments. (2) This experiment also addresses how political participation and empowerment affects the well-being of a marginalized population.

q16.value: We have four sets of hypotheses of short-term and long-run effects. These are: H1: the durbars increase women’s participation in local politics. H2: the durbars (a) Increase political parties’ outreach to both men and women (b) Reduce political parties’ intimidation of voters (c) Increase the proportion of political parties’ outreach activities and offers of benefits that are directed towards women H3: in the short term and the long run, the durbars cause both men and women to view women's political participation as more socially appropriate. H4: in the long run, the durbars (a) Improve women's access to government social protection programs and assistance from political parties. (b) Improve women's sense of financial independence from men and their beliefs about their economic position within their communities.

q17.value: The treatment is administered at the community (cluster) level, and it is assigned through pairwise randomization. The primary instrument for measurement of outcomes is a panel survey (baseline, endline, and second endline) of approximately 25 women and a close male relative for each woman per community. We focus on testing sharp null hypotheses of no effect at the community level (cluster level). Effect sizes at the community level will be calculated as the difference in means between treatment and control communities. The community-level measure of outcomes will be calculated as the mean of a standardized index constructed from individual-level responses from multiple items on the endline survey. When pre-treatment measures are available, we will use the mean of the index of individual-level differences from the baseline to endline survey at the community-level measure. The sharp null hypotheses of no effect for any unit will be tested with randomization inference. We will use a rank-based test statistic for pairwise randomized experiments. In addition, the overall population average treatment effects (equivalent to the weighted average of the cluster-level average treatment effects, with weights proportional to the cluster sample size) are our secondary estimands. These will be estimated with regression, with robust cluster standard errors, both without covariates and with covariates identified before endline data is collected.

q19.value: 44 communities, with approximately 50 survey respondents in each community

attributes.title: Wording Experiment on Election Cybersecurity Concerns in 2018 CCES

q1.value: Wording Experiment on Election Cybersecurity Concerns in 2018 CCES

q2.value: Lisa A. Bryant | Lonna R. Atkeson | Evan Crawford | Paul Gronke | Christopher Mann

q5.value: We would like to thank Reed College and the Democracy Fund for their ongoing support for our participation in the CCES, including this project. , We would also like to thank Christopher B. Mann and Paul Manson for help with the development of the survey instrument.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This survey experiment tests whether the wording of questions about election cybersecurity influences the level of concern expressed in public opinion surveys. This experiment is motivated by long-standing understanding of the impact of question wording, especially about technical terminology. We apply the question wording principle to the recent election cybersecurity area.

q16.value: Treatments o Random assignment of wording in questions about cyber-security between “hacking” or “breaking” o 50%-50% assignment between options o See the pre-analysis plan for full treatment text Hypotheses - H1: The use of “hacking” and “breaking” will produce different outcomes. o H0: No difference between treatments o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation. Heterogeneity/moderator hypotheses - HTrump_supp: The difference between “hacking” and “breaking” will vary conditional on the respondent’s support for President Trump. o President’s rhetoric will influence receptivity to framing ▪ Plan to conduct content analysis on frequency of using each term in public rhetoric to determine direction o Two tailed hypothesis: No a priori directional expectation. - HRussia: The difference between “hacking” and “breaking” will vary conditional on the respondent’s belief President Trump colluded with Russia in 2016 election. o Russia is tightly linked to hacking accusations, so this belief likely to be correlated with receptivity to treatment o Two tailed hypothesis: No a priori directional expectation. - Hstate_comp: The difference between “hacking” and “breaking” will vary conditional on the competitiveness of statewide elections in the respondent’s state. o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation - Hcong_comp: The difference between “hacking” and “breaking” will vary conditional on the competitiveness of the Congressional election in the respondent’s US House district. o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation - Hvote_mach: The difference between “hacking” and “breaking” will vary conditional on the type of voting machine(s) used in respondent’s state. o Citizens experience with paper ballots, DRE, and VVPATs will influence perception of vulnerability to cyber-attacks. ▪ Especially RCO371 and RCO374 o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation. - Hpartisan: The difference between “hacking” and “breaking” will vary conditional on the respondent’s partisanship. o Citizens affiliated with different parties will respond to different terms due to differential exposure. o Test with 5 point party scale (see below) o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation. - Hideology: The difference between “hacking” and “breaking” will vary conditional on the respondent’s ideology. o Citizens with different ideologies will respond to different terms due to differential exposure. o Test with 5 point ideology scale (see below) o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation. - Hrace: The difference between “hacking” and “breaking” will vary conditional on the respondent’s race/ethnicity. o Citizens from different race/ethnicity will respond to different terms due to differential exposure. o Test with race as defined in covariates below o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation - Heduc: The difference between “hacking” and “breaking” will vary conditional on the respondent’s education. o Citizens with different education levels will respond to different terms due to differential exposure to and/or understanding of terms. o Test with education as defined in covariates below o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation. - Hballot_confid: The difference between “hacking” and “breaking” will vary conditional on the respondent’s confidence in whether ballots are cast as counted. o Test with confidence in institutions at four levels: self (RCO310), local (RCO311), state (RCO312), national (RCO313) o Especially national confidence (RCO313) for national cyber security questions (RCO373-375) and local confidence (RCO311) for local cyber security questions (RCO370-372) o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation. - Hinstit_confid: The difference between “hacking” and “breaking” will vary conditional on the respondent’s confidence in government institutions. o Test with confidence in institutions at three levels: national (RCO301); state (RCO302) and local (Local Government GPA, see covariate details) o Use confidence measure appropriate to level ▪ RCO301 (federal) for national cyber security ▪ RCO302 (state) and Local Government GPA (see covariate details) for local cyber security o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation. - H2018_vote: The difference between “hacking” and “breaking” will vary conditional on the respondent’s voting behavior in 2018. o Citizens’ experience with voter registration, mail ballots, early voting, and Election Day voting may influence response to treatments. ▪ Especially RCO371 and RCO374 o Note: this covariate is only available for people who complete the post-election wave of the survey (attrition is expected) o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation. - H2016_vote: The difference between “hacking” and “breaking” will vary conditional on whether the respondent reports having voted in the 2016 election. o Citizens’ experience with voter registration, mail ballots, early voting, and Election Day voting may influence response to treatments. o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation. - Hvote_meth: The difference between “hacking” and “breaking” will vary conditional on the voting methods available in respondent’s state. o Citizens’ experience with mail ballots, early voting, and Election Day voting may influence response to treatments. ▪ Especially RCO371 and RCO374 o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation. - Hvote_reg: The difference between “hacking” and “breaking” will vary conditional on the voter registration methods available in respondent’s state. o Citizens’ experience with EDR, OVR, and AVR may influence response to treatments. ▪ Especially RCO370 and RCO373 o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation. - HEPI: The difference between “hacking” and “breaking” will vary conditional on the quality of election administration in the respondent’s state. o Different aggregate experience with and perception of state election administration will lead to different responses to terms. o Continuous measure using EPI – linear fit o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional/slope expectation - Hengage: The difference between “hacking” and “breaking” will vary conditional on respondent’s engagement in political activities. o Define high/low at median observed value o Citizens with different levels of engagement will respond to different terms due to differential exposure. o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation - Hknowledge: The difference between “hacking” and “breaking” will vary conditional on respondent’s factual knowledge about politics. o Define high/low at median observed value o Citizens with different levels of factual knowledge about politics will respond to different terms due to differential exposure. o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation - Hnews_int: The difference between “hacking” and “breaking” will vary conditional on respondent’s self-reported level of interest in political news. o Define high/low at median observed value o Citizens with different levels of interest in political news will respond to different terms due to differential exposure. o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation - Hmode: The difference between “hacking” and “breaking” will vary conditional on whether the respondent takes survey on phone/tablet or computer. o Tech interface could prime response about this question o Survey mode influences responses in many ways o Two tailed hypothesis: No directional expectation

q17.value: Outcomes Each of the following survey questions will be analyzed to determine if the treatments produce: a) a different distribution of responses across their 4 point scale; b) different proportions of “A major problem” responses; c) different proportions of “Not a problem at all”. See appendix for full questions and response scale. 1) RCO370 – Local: Voter registration 2) RCO371 – Local: Voting machines 3) RCO372 – Local: Campaigns 4) RCO373 – National: Voter registration 5) RCO374 – National: Voting machines 6) RCO375 – National: Campaigns Analysis: - Regression of each outcome measure on dummies for treatment conditions, with one condition omitted as the reference point since there is no untreated control group in this experiment. o All regressions will also include a series of covariates from the CCES (detailed below). - Change in distribution of responses will be assessed using ordered logit for the 4 point ordered outcome responses scale. o Results will be converted for interpretation with all covariates held at mean values. - Change in proportion of “A major problem” and “Not a problem at all” responses will be assessed using logistic regression. o Results will be converted for interpretation with all covariates held at mean values. - Heterogeneous treatment effects will be tested using interactions of relevant covariates and treatment indicators. - Full assumptions of Rubin-Neyman model of causal inference from randomized experiments. Therefore, use classical hypothesis testing of average treatment effect based robust SEs.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: This study aims to understand how Americans form preferences about international alliances. Previous work on public opinion about foreign policy suggests that the public uses the characteristics of other countries as informational shortcuts when forming preferences about international relations and American foreign policy. For example, some studies suggest that the American public distinguishes between countries based on their regime type. However, there are real-world examples in which the U.S. cooperates with countries the public would not be expected to support (such as autocracies) based on the findings of the scholarly research on public opinion about foreign policy. This study explores the conditions under which the American public might support an alliance between the United States and an unlikely alliance partner such as those described above. Specifically, does the existence of a critical threat increase individuals’ willingness to support an alliance between the United States and an unappealing or even threatening country? To answer these questions, this study uses a 2 x 2 x 2 factorial design to test the influence of two country characteristics and the goal of the alliance on individuals’ willingness to support the international alliance, beliefs about whether the potential alliance is in the best interest of the United States, and beliefs about the likely consequences of the potential alliance. Participants are presented with a short scenario indicating the U.S. is considering forming an alliance with another country. The scenario describes the goals of the alliance (general, or to combat ISIS) in addition to the characteristics of the country (regime type and respect for human rights). Additionally, participants are randomly presented one of two quotes by President Trump suggesting potential cooperation with Russia, asked whether they would support forming an alliance with Russia, and asked whether they believe such an alliance to be in the best interest of the United States.

q16.value: Main Effects First, I aim to test the following hypotheses regarding the influence of the characteristics of a potential alliance partner on individuals’ support for a potential alliance: 1. Describing the potential alliance partner as authoritarian should decrease support for the alliance, compared to describing the ally as democratic. 2. Describing the potential alliance partner as authoritarian should decrease individuals’ belief that the alliance is in the best interest of the United States, compared to describing the ally as democratic. 3. Describing the potential alliance partner as often violating human rights should decrease support for the alliance, compared to describing the ally as rarely violating human rights. 4. Describing the potential alliance partner as often violating human rights should decrease individuals’ belief that the alliance is in the best interest of the United States, compared to describing the ally as rarely violating human rights. Second, and most central to this study, I aim to test the following main hypotheses regarding the influence of alliance goal and threat on individuals’ support for a potential alliance: 5. Describing the goal of the alliance as combatting terrorism will increase support for the alliance, compared to the ‘general’ alliance condition, which does not mention a specific threat. 6. Describing the goal of the alliance as combatting terrorism will increase beliefs that the alliance is in the best interest of the United States, compared to the ‘general’ alliance condition, which does not mention a specific threat. Conditional Effects I expect the effects of 1) the country’s characteristics and 2) the goal of the alliance on individuals’ support for the alliance and belief that the alliance is in the best interest of the U.S. to be conditional: 1. The effect of regime type should be conditional on the alliance goal. In particular, I expect that describing the potential alliance partner as authoritarian (rather than democratic) will decrease support for the alliance and beliefs the alliance is in the best interest of the U.S., except in the case that the goal of the alliance is to fight terrorism. 2. The effect of the country’s human rights record should be conditional on the alliance goal. In particular, I expect that describing the country as often violating human rights will decrease support for the alliance and beliefs the alliance is in the best interest of the U.S., except in the case that the goal of the alliance is to fight terrorism. 3. The effect of the goal of the alliance should be conditional on whether individuals believe ISIS poses a threat. I expect that describing the goal of the alliance as to fight terrorism will only increase support for the alliance and beliefs the alliance is in the best interest of the U.S. when individuals believe ISIS poses a critical threat. In addition, I will also test whether results about a hypothetical alliance extend to a real-world example with the following hypothesis: 1. Individuals that read a quote by the president about cooperating with Russia with the goal of fighting ISIS will indicate relatively greater support for such cooperation, compared to those that receive the ‘general’ cooperation quote, which specifies Russia as a cooperation partner but does not mention ISIS. 2. Individuals that read a quote by the president about cooperating with Russia with the goal of fighting ISIS will indicate relatively stronger beliefs that such cooperation is in the best interest of the United States, compared to those that receive the ‘general’ cooperation quote, which specifies Russia as a cooperation partner but does not mention ISIS. 3. Individuals who are co-partisans with the president suggesting cooperation with Russia should indicate greater support for the proposed cooperation on average, than non-copartisans. 4. Individuals who indicate greater support for the president that suggested cooperation with Russia should indicate greater support for the proposed cooperation on average, than individuals indicating lower levels of support. 5. Individuals that perceive Russia to pose a critical threat to the United States should indicate less support for cooperation with Russia than those that perceive Russia as posing no threat or only somewhat of a threat. 6. The effect of the goal of cooperation with Russia should be conditional on whether individuals believe ISIS poses a threat. I expect that describing the goal of cooperation with Russia as fighting terrorism will only increase support for cooperation when individuals believe ISIS poses a critical threat. 7. The effect of the goal of cooperation with Russia may be conditional on whether individuals are co-partisans with the president. It might be that describing the goal as fighting terrorism increases support for cooperation when individuals are co-partisans with the president, because the newly introduced threat is more credible coming from a co-partisan source. On the other hand, it might be that the goal increases support for cooperation more among non-copartisans, because co-partisans were already more supportive of the cooperation. Mechanisms In order to identify the mechanisms underlying relationship between the goal of the alliance and individuals’ support for the alliance, the following hypotheses will also be tested: 1. Describing the alliance partner as authoritarian and a frequent violator of human rights should increase individuals’ perceptions of costs of the alliance. 2. Describing the goal of the alliance as fighting terrorism should increase individuals’ perceptions of the benefits of the alliance. 3. Beliefs that the alliance will help the U.S. fight terrorism should mediate the relationship between the goal of the alliance and individuals’ support for the alliance and beliefs the alliance is in the best interest of the United States. I expect that describing the goal of the alliance as fighting terrorism will increase support for the alliance and beliefs the alliance is in the best interest of the U.S. by increasing individuals’ beliefs the alliance will help the U.S. fight terrorism. The following research questions, which explore the relationship between individual-level characteristics and support for alliances, may also be explored: 1. Is support for a hypothetical alliance influenced by individuals’ foreign policy attitudes? 2. Is support for a hypothetical alliance influenced by individuals’ personal values? 3. Is support for a hypothetical alliance influenced by individuals’ level of political knowledge or partisan affiliations? If partisan affiliations influence support for the alliance, is it due to more concern among Republicans about terrorism?

q17.value: The main outcome variable is respondent support for the potential alliance. Support for the potential alliance is measured in two ways. First, individuals are asked to indicate support for the potential alliance on a scale from 0 to 100, where 0 indicates “definitely do not support the decision to ally with this country” and 100 indicates “definitely do support the decision to ally with this country.” Second, individuals are asked to indicate their beliefs that this alliance would be in the best interest of the United States. Individuals are again presented a scale from 0 to 100 where 0 indicates “forming this military alliance is definitely not in the best interest of the United States” and 100 indicates “forming this military alliance is definitely in the best interest of the United States.” In both questions, individuals are also able to instead answer “Don’t Know.” For ease of interpretation, these measures may also be dichotomized, where numbers less than 50 are interpreted as lack of support for the alliance (beliefs the alliance is not in the best interest of the U.S.) and numbers greater than 50 are interpreted as support for the alliance (beliefs that the alliance is in the best interest of the U.S.). Beliefs about the costs and benefits of the alliance are measured by asking individuals to indicate their beliefs about potential consequences, if the U.S. were to form the alliance. Individuals are asked to indicate beliefs on a scale from 0 to 100, where 0 means the individual believes the consequence is “extremely unlikely” and 100 means the consequence is “extremely likely.” The potential consequences are as follows: (1) Americans will be safer, (2) the alliance will provoke or anger other countries, (3) the U.S. will be pulled into unwanted wars, (4) the other country will honor the alliance agreement, (5) ISIS will be defeated or significantly weakened, (6) The reputation of the U.S. will be hurt, and (7) the U.S. government will have the freedom it needs to make necessary foreign policy decisions. Beliefs about the threat posed by terrorism are measured in two ways: first, I ask individuals to indicate whether they believe ISIS poses “no threat at all,” “somewhat of a threat,” or “a critical threat” to the United States. I also ask individuals which of 6 foreign policy goals they believe “is the most important foreign policy goal facing the U.S. today,” where “Taking measures to protect the U.S. from terrorism” is one option. Beliefs about the threat of Russia are measured similarly. Main hypotheses will be tested using OLS regression. Individuals’ beliefs about the characteristics of the potential ally (e.g. location, military power) were also measured post-treatment and may be used as controls if the treatments significantly influenced individuals’ perceptions of the alliance partner in unintended ways. Additionally, respondents’ demographic characteristics may be used as controls in the case that treatment groups are unbalanced.

attributes.title: The Impact of Reconstruction-Era Amnesty Policy on Elite Persistence in the Postbellum South

q1.value: The Impact of Reconstruction-Era Amnesty Policy on Elite Persistence in the Postbellum South

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This project investigates the impact of Reconstruction-era amnesty policy on the political participation and wealth accumulation of planter elites in the postbellum U.S. South. Amnesty policy restricted the political and economic rights of the planter class for nearly three years during Reconstruction. The project estimates the effect of being excepted from amnesty on elites' wealth and political power using a regression discontinuity design. Preliminary results on a sample of southern white delegates to Reconstruction conventions show that being excepted in the $20,000 class substantially decreases the likelihood of holding ex-post political office. The preliminary results help explain changes to the identity of the southern Democratic party elite across the Civil War and Reconstruction.

q16.value: I hypothesize that amnesty policy had a deleterious effect on the public service participation of elites; that is, individuals excepted in the $20,000 class are less likely to hold office (H1) or run for office (H2) following the granting of general amnesty in 1868. I hypothesize that amnesty policy had a negative or no impact on the accumulated wealth ending in 1870 (H3). I expect the county-level number of individuals excepted in the $20,000 class to decrease party competition after universal amnesty was granted (H4). I hypothesize that county-level treatment decreases black disenfranchisement (H5), violence against black officeholders (H6), and lynching incidents against blacks (H7). I expect treatment to decrease the black illiteracy rate (H8), increase the black public school attendance rate (H9), and increase the number of black public school teachers (H10) and Rosenwald Schools available to black children (H11).

q17.value: The present study compares white southern males marginally above and below $20,000 to estimate the intention-to-treat (ITT) effect of being excepted from amnesty as a result of belonging to the $20,000 class. County-level treatment effects are estimated by regressing outcomes aggregated at the county level on the number of individuals excepted in the $20,000 class.

attributes.title: Experiment on Support for Automatic Voter Registration in CCES 2018 Pre-Election Wave

q1.value: Experiment on Support for Automatic Voter Registration in CCES 2018 Pre-Election Wave

q2.value: Lisa A. Bryant | Lonna R. Atkeson | Evan Crawford | Paul Gronke | Christopher Mann

q5.value: We would like to thank Reed College and the Democracy Fund for their ongoing support for our participation in the CCES, including this project. , We would also like to thank Christopher B. Mann and Paul Manson for help with the development of the survey instrument.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This survey experiment tests whether the public’s expectations about the impact of automatic voter registration (AVR) is shaped by cues about political elite support for the policy. Oregon was the first state to adopt and implement automatic voter registration prior to the 2016 election. Following Oregon, 15 additional states (plus DC) have adopted automatic voter registration, although the details of the process vary by state. For this experiment, automatic voter registration is defined by the most common approach in recent state legislation: citizens who obtain or update a driver’s license or state ID are automatically registered to vote. Survey research by scholars, news media pollsters, and private groups have examined public support for passing automatic voter registration. Referenda to pass automatic voter registration in several states provides additional (and legally binding) indications of public support. However, to our knowledge, no research has explored public expectations of impacts of the policy. Since support for adopting automatic voter registration in different states has come from different types of political elites, examining how these cues shape public expectations is an opportunity to gain insights about the opinion dynamics about public policy – both for this particular election reform and public policy generally. Although many proposals to alter election administration are bogged down in partisan “voting wars”, automatic voter registration has been adopted in states controlled by Democrats and Republicans. Democrats and Republicans make different arguments in favor of automatic voter registration, but the legislative track record suggests each partisan camp seems to have found something to like. One purpose of the survey experiment is testing whether framing automatic voter registration (AVR) using partisan language activates partisan processing on the part of the respondent and thus alters expectations about the policy outcomes from AVR. This part of the experiment is motivated by recent research that shows that partisan framing has a strong impact on evaluation of policies, reforms, and evaluations of political leaders. This research finds co-partisan framing tends to increase support, while framing in terms of the opposing party reduces support. However, as noted above, we are not aware of any research examining the impact of partisan framing on expectations about policy outcomes for AVR or other election reforms. We include “dual” partisan framing because AVR was passed in some states with support from both parties. We extend testing of elite cues beyond partisanship by including “election officials” as non-partisan bureaucratic experts. Election officials have made non-partisan (or at least less partisan) arguments supporting automatic voter registration due to cost-savings and reduced election administration problems. This condition reflects a (potentially) important part of the policy debate influencing expectations about policy impacts. As part of the 2018 CCES Module for Reed College, the experiment tests the impact of cuing citizens to think of automatic voter registration as supported by Democrats, Republicans, both parties, election administrators. A control condition omits any cue about political elite support. Following the randomly assigned cue, respondents are asked about their expectations of the impact of automatic voter registration on election fairness and legitimacy, election administration problems, voter turnout and voter fraud. We expect these cues about political elite support for automatic voter registration will alter public beliefs about the impact of reforms. The pattern of effects is expected to be similar in direction to partisan debates about a range of election administration reforms, however it is unclear how strong these partisan effects will be. Support from election officials is expected to decrease concerns about election administration problems and voter fraud and expected to increase positive beliefs about fairness and turnout.

q16.value: Treatments o Random assignment of a statement about different types of political elite support for automatic voter registration embedded in question about the impact of this reform on four outcomes (election fairness, administrative problems, voter turnout, and voter fraud) o Even (20%) assignment to each treatment condition 1 control, no additional text 1 Democratic leaders support automatic voter registration because they say it improves elections. 2 Republicans leaders support automatic voter registration because they say it improves elections. 3 Democrats and Republicans support automatic voter registration because they say it improves elections. 4 State and local election administrators support automatic voter registration because they say it improves elections. o The base question includes brief description of automatic voter registration and mentions major benefits associated with each side of the partisan debate on election reform. o Description: “automatically register voters when they get or renew their driver’s license” o Access argument (liberal): “increase the number of people registered” o Security argument (conservative) : “make the lists more accurate” o See the pre-analysis plan for full treatment text Hypotheses - H1: Each political elite support cue will change expectations about the impact of automatic voter registration relative to the control. o H0: No difference between treatment and control o One tailed hypotheses: ▪ Fairness and Problem outcomes: Each treatment condition will cause shift toward “better” for fairness and problems. ▪ Fraud outcome: Republican cue, Bipartisan cue and Election Official cue will cause shift toward “decrease” for fraud. ▪ Turnout outcome: Democratic cue and Bipartisan cue will cause shift toward “increase” for turnout. o Two tailed hypotheses: ▪ Turnout outcome: No definitive expectation about direction of effect on turnout from Republican cue and Election official cue. ▪ Fraud outcome: No definitive expectation about direction of effect on fraud from Democratic cue. - H2: Each political elite support cue will produce different expectations about the impact of automatic voter registration than the other cues. o H0: No difference between treatments o One tailed hypotheses: ▪ Fairness and Problem outcomes: Bipartisan cue and Election official cue will cause larger shifts toward “better” for fairness and problems than Democratic cue or Republican cue. ▪ Skepticism from respondents identifying with opposite party will attenuate effects for Democratic and Republican cues. ▪ Fraud outcome: Democratic cue will cause smaller shift toward “decrease” for fraud than Bipartisan cue, Election official cue and Republican cue. ▪ Turnout outcome: Republican cue will cause smaller shift toward “increase” for turnout than Bipartisan cue, Election official cue and Democratic cue. o Two tailed hypotheses: ▪ Fairness and Problem outcomes: No definitive expectation about relative magnitudes of shift towards “better” for fairness and problems between Bipartisan cue and Election official cue. ▪ Fairness and Problem outcomes: No definitive expectation about relative magnitudes of shift towards “better” for fairness and problems between Democratic cue and Republican cue. ▪ Fraud outcome: No definitive expectation about relative magnitudes of shift towards “decrease” for fraud among Bipartisan cue, Election official cue and Republican cue. ▪ No strong prior about whether Democratic partisan skepticism will attenuate effects for Republican cue. ▪ Turnout outcome: No definitive expectation about relative magnitudes of shift towards “increase” for turnout among Bipartisan cue, Election official cue and Democratic cue. ▪ No strong prior about whether Republican partisan skepticism will attenuate effects for Democratic cue. registration_responses.q15: This survey experiment tests whether the public’s expectations about the impact of automatic voter registration (AVR) is shaped by cues about political elite support for the policy. Oregon was the first state to adopt and implement automatic voter registration prior to the 2016 election. Following Oregon, 15 additional states (plus DC) have adopted automatic voter registration, although the details of the process vary by state. For this experiment, automatic voter registration is defined by the most common approach in recent state legislation: citizens who obtain or update a driver’s license or state ID are automatically registered to vote. Survey research by scholars, news media pollsters, and private groups have examined public support for passing automatic voter registration. Referenda to pass automatic voter registration in several states provides additional (and legally binding) indications of public support. However, to our knowledge, no research has explored public expectations of impacts of the policy. Since support for adopting automatic voter registration in different states has come from different types of political elites, examining how these cues shape public expectations is an opportunity to gain insights about the opinion dynamics about public policy – both for this particular election reform and public policy generally. Although many proposals to alter election administration are bogged down in partisan “voting wars”, automatic voter registration has been adopted in states controlled by Democrats and Republicans. Democrats and Republicans make different arguments in favor of automatic voter registration, but the legislative track record suggests each partisan camp seems to have found something to like. One purpose of the survey experiment is testing whether framing automatic voter registration (AVR) using partisan language activates partisan processing on the part of the respondent and thus alters expectations about the policy outcomes from AVR. This part of the experiment is motivated by recent research that shows that partisan framing has a strong impact on evaluation of policies, reforms, and evaluations of political leaders. This research finds co-partisan framing tends to increase support, while framing in terms of the opposing party reduces support. However, as noted above, we are not aware of any research examining the impact of partisan framing on expectations about policy outcomes for AVR or other election reforms. We include “dual” partisan framing because AVR was passed in some states with support from both parties. We extend testing of elite cues beyond partisanship by including “election officials” as non-partisan bureaucratic experts. Election officials have made non-partisan (or at least less partisan) arguments supporting automatic voter registration due to cost-savings and reduced election administration problems. This condition reflects a (potentially) important part of the policy debate influencing expectations about policy impacts. As part of the 2018 CCES Module for Reed College, the experiment tests the impact of cuing citizens to think of automatic voter registration as supported by Democrats, Republicans, both parties, election administrators. A control condition omits any cue about political elite support. Following the randomly assigned cue, respondents are asked about their expectations of the impact of automatic voter registration on election fairness and legitimacy, election administration problems, voter turnout and voter fraud. We expect these cues about political elite support for automatic voter registration will alter public beliefs about the impact of reforms. The pattern of effects is expected to be similar in direction to partisan debates about a range of election administration reforms, however it is unclear how strong these partisan effects will be. Support from election officials is expected to decrease concerns about election administration problems and voter fraud and expected to increase positive beliefs about fairness and turnout.

attributes.title: Flex: a field experiment to investigate British consumer uptake to a ‘smart’ time of use tariff

q1.value: Flex: a field experiment to investigate British consumer uptake to a ‘smart’ time of use tariff

q5.value: Dr Gesche Huebner and Professor David Shipworth

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: The electrification of heat and transport is expected to place one of the biggest burdens on future electricity networks, especially at peak times such as weeknight evenings, when people return home from work. To mitigate this, governments are relying on domestic consumers to sign up to new types of smart-meter enabled electricity tariffs which will be designed to encourage them to use less electricity at peak times. For example, in the UK, the business case for smart meters relies on 20 percent of consumers switching to a time of use tariff (which charge people a higher rate for electricity consumed at peak times) by 2030. However, consumers rarely switch their energy tariff or supplier, despite the large savings involved. In Ireland, time of use tariffs will become mandatory. In the US, scholars and policymakers are advocating the use of an opt-out enrollment approach. However, consumers do not like being told what to do and these tariffs will not necessary benefit everyone. Moreover, evidence suggests that the effectiveness of opt-outs may originate from people's inattention to the default option. Whilst this may be a tolerable cost for boosting enrollment rates to pension schemes and organ donor registers (which are arguably in the majority of the public's interest), there is no point in enrolling people on tariffs without their knowledge as they are unlikely to adjust their electricity consumption patterns. Although third party automation of electrical demand (e.g home heating) could be used to avoid people from consuming at peak times, this still raises the question over how consent for such schemes would be obtained. One possibility is that suppliers will bundle these tariffs with third party control as part of the standard terms of conditions of the tariff. If people do not read terms and conditions, this presents a risk that people could sign up to automated control of their heating without their knowledge (raising ethical concerns, including over health and safety e.g. if elderly people sign up to automation without their knowledge and a supplier is able to reduce their heating demand temperatures). However, it is not known what proportion of people would fail to read the terms and conditions of such tariffs and therefore whether there is a genuine risk of this happening. An alternative approach would be for suppliers to actively prompt people to sign up to direct load control after they have switched to a time of use tariff – however, this may not result in a high enough number of sign ups to prevent people from losing money relative to a flat-rate tariff. This project will run a field experiment to test low-cost methods of recruiting owners of plug-in electric vehicles and/or heat pumps (which are expected to be the dominant form of heating in 2030) to domestic demand-side response electricity tariffs. It will also test methods of obtaining informed consent for direct load control and will analyse whether these tariffs self-select consumers who are most likely to save money on the tariff (consumers with high consuming flexible electrical appliances) or whether such tariffs may also attract consumers who could be worse off on a time of use tariff than on a flat-rate tariff - and whether some methods are more likely to increase uptake amongst those who are likely to save money than others. The tariff was designed by a British energy supplier to be commercially viable in the current climate. This study will be a randomised control trial in which two experiments will be run. Experiment 1 The first experiment will test two methods of boosting new customer registration rates – information provision and tailored information provision. Participants will be recruited through online advertisements and then randomly assigned to one of three versions of a website that was created especially for the trial in an A/B test style field experiment: • Control: existing company website, with multiple types of information but no pricing information (status quo) • Treatment group 1: price information with a price comparison • Treatment group 2: tailored price information Experiment 2 In addition, to test different methods of obtaining informed consent for additional home automation services, visitors will be randomly assigned within each of the three websites to one of two different ways of obtaining this consent: (1) third party direct load control of home heating is built into the standard terms and conditions of the tariff (bundled consent) (2) a text box informing them that the company could install a smart thermostat in their homes which the company will use to occasionally lower the temperature on their home heating during peak times help them save money on their energy bills which asks them to tick one of three boxes to indicate their preference: (i) yes they do want a smart thermostat which the energy company will remotely adjust at peak times or; (ii) they already have a smart thermostat but would like the company to remotely adjust the temperature set point at peak times or; (iii) they do not want the company to remotely adjust their heating (active choice). This imagines a future in which most people have electric heating and smart thermostats to which suppliers, with consent, could connect to automatically. We note that after participants assigned to the bundled condition switch, they are also asked to provide an active choice to whether or not they would like direct load control; this enables us to test whether they provided informed consent to DLC (as simply downloading the terms and conditions does not demonstrate that they read them and therefore were aware of the clause about direct load control). Therefore, the only difference between the active choice condition and the bundled condition is that the latter contains a clause that provides the supplier with permission to do direct load control whereas the terms and conditions in the former does not.

q16.value: Experiment 1 (H1a): get a quote rates and switching rates will be higher amongst those who are more likely to benefit from the time of use tariff (H1b): get a quote rates and switching rates will be no higher amongst those who are more likely to benefit from the time of use tariff (H2) get a quote and switching rates will be higher amongst those who self-report having an Economy 7 tariff/meter (H3): Get a quote rates will be higher in the price comparison condition than the control condition (H4): Get a quote rates will be higher in the tailored condition than the control condition (H5): Get a quote rates will be higher in the tailored condition than the price comparison condition (H6): Get a quote rates will be higher in the tailored condition than either the control or price comparison conditions amongst the population of interest (heat pump and electric vehicle owners). q17.value: Experiment 1 Hypotheses H1a-H1b will be tested by taking the total number of people who get a quote and dividing this by each of the key population sub-groups that indicate a greater likelihood of benefitting from the tariff: electric vehicle ownership, heat pump ownership, living in a house with over 4 bedrooms. Hypotheses H1a-H1b will be tested by taking the total number of people who switch to the tariff and dividing it by each of the following sub-groups: electric vehicle ownership, heat pump ownership, living in a house with over 4 bedrooms, those living in a household with electric heating, tumble dryer, washing machine, dishwasher, washer-dryer respectively. H2 will be tested by taking the total number of people who get a quote or switch and dividing this by the number of people who self-report having an Economy 7 tariff/meter. The proportions obtained will be compared to their general representation in the population. Hypotheses 3-4 will be tested using a logistic regression using the following two equations respectively: (1) (Y_i )=α+β_1 (T2)_i+ X_i+ u_i (2) (Y_i )=α+β_2 (T3)_i+ X_i+ u_i Hypothesis 5 will be tested using logistic regression using the following equation, in which the price comparison group is the omitted dummy variable and therefore the reference category: (3) (Y_i )=α+β_3 (T3)_i+ X_i+ u_i Hypothesis 6 will be tested using a logistic regression using the following equation, in which individuals assigned to the price comparison and control group combined are the reference category: (4) (Y_i )= α+ β_6 〖T3〗_i+ β_7 〖T3〗_i*〖δ.index〗_i+ β_8 〖δ.index〗_i+ J_i+ χ_i+ μ_i Hypothesis 5 will be tested using logistic regression using the following equation, in which the price comparison group is the omitted dummy variable and therefore the reference category: (Y_i )= α+ β_6 (T3)_i+ β_7 (T3)_i*(δ.index)_i+ β_8 (δ.index)_i+ J_i+ χ_i+ μ_i In all equations, Y_i is the outcome measure; it is a binary variable taking the value of one (1) if the participant gets a quote and (0) otherwise. α is the constant. In equation 1, the treatment dummy T2 indicates whether individual i was assigned to the price comparison website, rather than the control group. In equation 2, T3 indicates whether individual i was assigned to the tailored website rather than the control group. In equation 3, T3 indicates whether the individual i was assigned to the tailored website rather than the price comparison group. In equation 4, T3 indicates whether individual i was assigned to the tailored website rather than either the control or price comparison website. Each treatment dummy can either take on the value 0, indicating that the respondent was not in that group, or the value 1, indicating that the respondent was in that treatment group. In equation 1, β_1 is the coefficient on 〖T2〗_i, which measures the effect of being in the price comparison group rather than the control group and is our primary coefficient of interest for testing H3. In equation 2 β_2 is the coefficient on 〖T3〗_i, which measures the effect of being in the tailored group rather than the control group and is our primary coefficient of interest for testing H4. In equation 3, β_3 is the coefficient on 〖T3〗_i, which measures the effect of being in the tailored group rather than the price comparison group and is our primary coefficient of interest for testing H5. In equation 4, β_6 is the coefficient on 〖T3〗_i which measures the effect of being in the tailored group rather than the price comparison or control group amongst those for whom there are observations for the diagnostic indices (i.e. those who completed the surveys), whereas β_7 is the coefficient on the interaction term 〖T3〗_i*〖δ.index〗_i, which measures the effect of being in the tailored group rather than in the price comparison or control group amongst individuals who have a high value on the diagnostic index (e.g. self-report as having either an electric vehicle or a heat pump) compared to any individuals with a low value on the diagnostic index (i.e. did not report as having these appliances) and is therefore the coefficient of interest for testing H6. 〖δ.index〗_i in equation 4 is the dummy variable which indicates whether an individual has a high value on the diagnostic index (i.e. self-reported as having a heat pump or electric vehicle) compared to those who have a low value so β_8 is the coefficient on this variable which captures the effect of self-reporting to own one of these appliances on the outcome variable. As noted above, there are four diagnostic indices and each one will be used to estimate equation 4 respectively. In equation 4, the variable J_i is the propensity score (the inverse probability of completing the survey and therefore having contributed to the diagnostic index). If the coefficient on the diagnostic index is significant then this is evidence that the tariff is self-selecting people who are more likely to benefit from the tariff, in line with classical expectations; if it is not significant, then there is no evidence for this, as consistent with a behavioural economic framework. If the coefficient on both the treatment and the interaction between treatment and the diagnostic index are significant, then diagnosis is important (i.e. tailoring works better on heat pump and EV owners) but the treatment also works regardless of diagnostic status. If the coefficient on the treatment dummy is not significant but the coefficient on the treatment by diagnostic index interaction is significant, then treatment is contingent upon proper diagnosis. If we have the reverse, then the treatment is more universally effective and diagnostics are not important. If neither is significant, we cannot reject the hypothesis that the treatment doesn’t have an impact on anybody in the sample frame, diagnosed or not. Across all equations, X_i is a vector of control variables, which includes a series of individual characteristic controls including whether they are a new or returning visitor [binary 1=yes; 0=no], the referring advert (fixed effects), the device the website was viewed on [binary 1=computer; 0=mobile/tablet] and the time the website was visited (fixed effects). u_i is the error term. Multiple comparisons corrections will be applied treating experiment 1 and experiment 2 as independent sets of tests. Experiment 2 Hypothesis 1 will be tested using a logistic regression using the following equation respectively: (1) (Y_i )=α+β_1 〖T1〗_i+ X_i+ u_i In the equation above, Y_i is the outcome measure; it is a binary variable taking the value of one (1) if the participant provides consent for direct load control and (0) otherwise as per Table 2. α is the constant. The treatment dummy T1 indicates whether individual i was assigned to the active choice condition, rather than the bundled condition. β_1 is the coefficient on 〖T1〗_i, which measures the effect of being in the active choice condition rather than the bundled condition and is our primary coefficient of interest for testing H1. We expect a statistically significant negative coefficient. X_i is a vector of control variables, which includes a series of individual characteristic controls including whether they are a new or returning visitor [binary 1=yes; 0=no], the referring advert (fixed effects) and the device the website was viewed on [binary 1=computer; 0=mobile/tablet]; the time the website was visited (fixed effects) – to control for the fact that participants were randomly assigned to the active choice or bundled condition within each of the three website versions (stratified randomisation), X_i also includes two dummy variables indicating whether people were assigned to the price comparison or tailored condition, in which the control website is the omitted dummy and therefore reference category. u_i is the error term. Hypothesis 2 will be tested by comparing the proportion of people who download the terms and conditions within the bundled choice condition AND who switch to the tariff AND who also consent to DLC when later given an active choice to the proportion of people within the active choice condition who consent to DLC.

registration_responses.q1: Flex: a field experiment to investigate British consumer uptake to a ‘smart’ time of use tariff
registration_responses.q5: Dr Gesche Huebner and Professor David Shipworth
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to assignment of treatment
registration_responses.q15: The electrification of heat and transport is expected to place one of the biggest burdens on future electricity networks, especially at peak times such as weeknight evenings, when people return home from work. To mitigate this, governments are relying on domestic consumers to sign up to new types of smart-meter enabled electricity tariffs which will be designed to encourage them to use less electricity at peak times. For example, in the UK, the business case for smart meters relies on 20 percent of consumers switching to a time of use tariff (which charge people a higher rate for electricity consumed at peak times) by 2030. However, consumers rarely switch their energy tariff or supplier, despite the large savings involved. In Ireland, time of use tariffs will become mandatory. In the US, scholars and policymakers are advocating the use of an opt-out enrollment approach. However, consumers do not like being told what to do and these tariffs will not necessary benefit everyone. Moreover, evidence suggests that the effectiveness of opt-outs may originate from people's inattention to the default option. Whilst this may be a tolerable cost for boosting enrollment rates to pension schemes and organ donor registers (which are arguably in the majority of the public's interest), there is no point in enrolling people on tariffs without their knowledge as they are unlikely to adjust their electricity consumption patterns. Although third party automation of electrical demand (e.g home heating) could be used to avoid people from consuming at peak times, this still raises the question over how consent for such schemes would be obtained. One possibility is that suppliers will bundle these tariffs with third party control as part of the standard terms of conditions of the tariff. If people do not read terms and conditions, this presents a risk that people could sign up to automated control of their heating without their knowledge (raising ethical concerns, including over health and safety e.g. if elderly people sign up to automation without their knowledge and a supplier is able to reduce their heating demand temperatures). However, it is not known what proportion of people would fail to read the terms and conditions of such tariffs and therefore whether there is a genuine risk of this happening. An alternative approach would be for suppliers to actively prompt people to sign up to direct load control after they have switched to a time of use tariff – however, this may not result in a high enough number of sign ups to prevent people from losing money relative to a flat-rate tariff. This project will run a field experiment to test low-cost methods of recruiting owners of plug-in electric vehicles and/or heat pumps (which are expected to be the dominant form of heating in 2030) to domestic demand-side response electricity tariffs. It will also test methods of obtaining informed consent for direct load control and will analyse whether these tariffs self-select consumers who are most likely to save money on the tariff (consumers with high consuming flexible electrical appliances) or whether such tariffs may also attract consumers who could be worse off on a time of use tariff than on a flat-rate tariff - and whether some methods are more likely to increase uptake amongst those who are likely to save money than others. The tariff was designed by a British energy supplier to be commercially viable in the current climate. This study will be a randomised control trial in which two experiments will be run. Experiment 1 The first experiment will test two methods of boosting new customer registration rates – information provision and tailored information provision. Participants will be recruited through online advertisements and then randomly assigned to one of three versions of a website that was created especially for the trial in an A/B test style field experiment: • Control: existing company website, with multiple types of information but no pricing information (status quo) • Treatment group 1: price information with a price comparison • Treatment group 2: tailored price information Experiment 2 In addition, to test different methods of obtaining informed consent for additional home automation services, visitors will be randomly assigned within each of the three websites to one of two different ways of obtaining this consent: (1) third party direct load control of home heating is built into the standard terms and conditions of the tariff (bundled consent) (2) a text box informing them that the company could install a smart thermostat in their homes which the company will use to occasionally lower the temperature on their home heating during peak times help them save money on their energy bills which asks them to tick one of three boxes to indicate their preference: (i) yes they do want a smart thermostat which the energy company will remotely adjust at peak times or; (ii) they already have a smart thermostat but would like the company to remotely adjust the temperature set point at peak times or; (iii) they do not want the company to remotely adjust their heating (active choice). This imagines a future in which most people have electric heating and smart thermostats to which suppliers, with consent, could connect to automatically. We note that after participants assigned to the bundled condition switch, they are also asked to provide an active choice to whether or not they would like direct load control; this enables us to test whether they provided informed consent to DLC (as simply downloading the terms and conditions does not demonstrate that they read them and therefore were aware of the clause about direct load control). Therefore, the only difference between the active choice condition and the bundled condition is that the latter contains a clause that provides the supplier with permission to do direct load control whereas the terms and conditions in the former does not.

attributes.title: Changing Attitudes Towards Campaign Finance Reform: Evidence from a Canvassing Experiment

q1.value: Changing Attitudes Towards Campaign Finance Reform: Evidence from a Canvassing Experiment

q2.value: Michael Schwam-Baird | Donald Green | Jonathan Krasno | Costas Panagopoulos | Kyle Endres

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: This study examines whether in-person conversations with a canvasser can alter opinions about campaign finance reform. We hope to understand whether in-person persuasion can alter both the direction of a person's opinion and the salience of the issue.

q16.value: 1) Does providing arguments for or against campaign finance reform during an in-person conversation alter attitudes towards campaign finance regulation? We anticipate that canvassing messages will move targets in the direction of the arguments presented. We also anticipate that individuals with lower interest in campaigns and who are less partisan to begin with will alter their opinions the most in reaction to canvassing. 2) Do in-person conversations about campaign finance reform increase the salience of campaign finance regulation as an issue? We anticipate that receiving either campaign finance reform message will increase the salience of the issue relative to the group that receives the placebo. We also anticipate that individuals with lower interest in campaigns and who are less partisan to begin with will alter their opinions about the importance of the issue the most in reaction to canvassing.

q17.value: We will use ordered logit, logit, and OLS models to estimate the effect of treatment on a series of dependent variables gathered using a survey. We will calculate significance using typical parametric standard error estimates from the R statistical package as well as randomization inference.

attributes.title: Voter views of varieties of clientelism

q1.value: Voter views of varieties of clientelism

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: This study seeks to test 1) whether voters receive signals about candidates’ characteristics from the forms of clientelism that those candidates engage in, and 2) whether voters punish or reward different forms of clientelism in different ways.

q16.value: a) Electoral support H1a: Voters will be less likely to support a candidate who engages in electoral coercion relative to electoral handouts. H1b: Voters will be less likely to support a candidate who engages in electoral handouts relative to the control group. b) Informational signals H2a: Voters will perceive candidates who engage in electoral coercion relative to electoral handouts as having less positive qualities. H2b: Voters will perceive candidates who engage in electoral handouts relative to the control condition as having less positive qualities. c) Heterogeneous effects H3a: Poorer voters will be less likely to punish candidates who engage in electoral handouts relative to the control group. H3b: Poorer voters will perceive candidates who engage in electoral handouts less negatively relative to the control group. H4a: Voters who are ineligible for the workfare program will be less likely to punish candidates who engage in electoral coercion. H4b: Voters who are ineligible for the workfare program will perceive candidates who engage in electoral handouts less negatively relative to the control group.

q17.value: This section outlines the measures that we will use for outcomes, heterogeneous effects analysis, and controls. We will construct mean effects indices and standardize all continuous measures. a) Outcomes – Electoral support Voter propensity to support the candidate. We will measure the perceived capacity of candidate’s with two questions measured on a five-point scale: • How likely is it that you would vote for this candidate? • How likely is it that you would vote for another candidate? (reverse coded) • How likely is it that you would not vote at all? (reverse coded) b) Outcomes - Informational Signals Our main tests will be based on indices that combine the following equally-weighted characteristics. Likelihood of winning the election. We will measure the perceived likelihood that a candidate will win the election with two questions measured on a five-point scale: • If this mayor would run for office in your locality, how likely is it that he would have the votes of some people in the locality? • If this mayor would run for office in your locality, how likely is it that he would win the election? Candidate’s capacity. We will measure the perceived capacity of candidate’s with a battery of questions asking voters to assess the following characteristics on a five-point scale: • How good manager do you think this candidate is? • How likely is it that this candidate is capable of ensuring order and discipline in the village? • How likely is it that this candidate can solve things in town? Candidate’s positive personal characteristics. We will measure the perceived positive characteristics of the candidate with a battery of questions asking voters to assess the following characteristics on a five-point scale: • How likely is it that this candidate knows how to treat people? • How likely is it that this candidate helps poor people? • How likely is it that this candidate would help people in an emergency? • How likely is it that this candidate is a good Christian? • How likely is it that this candidate is a good family man? Candidate’s corruption. We will measure the perceived corruption of candidate’s with a battery of questions asking voters to assess the following characteristics on a five-point scale: • How honest do you think this candidate is? • How likely is it that this candidate is against corruption? c) Heterogeneous Effects Poverty. We will measure poverty using the respondents’ self-reported income on a four-point scale. The measure will be reverse-coded. As a robustness check, we will also look at subjective poverty. Eligibility for the workfare program. We will code someone as ineligible for the workfare program if they report their occupation as: • Employed • Retired d) Controls Our main specifications will include controls for gender, age, education, ethnicity, income, occupation, and partisan affiliation.
